content: This is a landing area for newcomers who are interested in helping the Rust Compiler team with its goal for 2022!
hi, I'm Oluwasomidotun from Nigeria, I just started using Rust and wanted to try it out and see how much it could help me get better

hi there @Oluwasomidotun ! if you just started using Rust, you may want to skim over the topics in #general , or start a new one there yourself with any specific questions you have or topics you want to discuss
but in any case, welcome !

Hey, I just read the Compiler 2022 blog post.
I'm interested in contributing to the diagnostics, especially to make Rust easier for newcomers.
However, I don't have a lot of experience with compilers and am just getting started with setting up rustc.
Are there any low hanging fruits to get started?

Hey, I'd love to help with Chalk integration. Is it something that makes sense as a first contribution?
I'm writing Rust at work now, have a CS background and am superficially familiar with prolog if that helps.
Is it appropriate to just ping the task owners here?

TimJentzsch said:

Hey, I just read the Compiler 2022 blog post.
I'm interested in contributing to the diagnostics, especially to make Rust easier for newcomers.
However, I don't have a lot of experience with compilers and am just getting started with setting up rustc.
Are there any low hanging fruits to get started?

I'm not familiar with any low-hanging fruit (that's not to say there isn't any). You might be interested in looking at A-diagnostics issues on github (https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AA-diagnostics). Or maybe even A-diagnostics + E-easy (https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AA-diagnostics+label%3AE-easy).

Kinrany said:

Hey, I'd love to help with Chalk integration. Is it something that makes sense as a first contribution?
I'm writing Rust at work now, have a CS background and am superficially familiar with prolog if that helps.
Is it appropriate to just ping the task owners here?

Hey :wave: Doing some chalk-related work isn't a bad start for a first contribution :) Feel free to open a thread in #wg-traits, and I'll also see if I can come up with some good tasks

If you're just getting yourself set up with rust-development, there's a couple different resources we can point you all at. First of all, there is #t-compiler/help , a stream where people are all about just asking whatever random problems you're running into with whatever you're trying to do.
but before you jump in there, you probably should look over the Rustc Dev Guide: https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/
(not all of the rustc-dev-guide; its long! but the parts about just how you get started.)

Hi, I'm also a new member coming from the blog post. I would like to give some help but I don't know really where I could be of help yet. I'm starting to read the Rustc Dev Guide to get some knowledge. During my CS degree we made a compiler for a basic language so I know a bit about the basics but that's all my knowledge. If you know where I could be of help, feel free to ping me as I would enjoy at lot some guidance.

Hi! I'd also like to help with developing the compiler in my free time. I have worked on a few diagnostics improvements, stable hashing performance and Python debugger formatters so far. I'm usually trying to find work by profiling the compiler on various crates, but it's a bit random and the "success rate" is quite small. If anyone has e.g. some performance experiments that they want to try, but lack the bandwidth, or some (entry) level tasks in other areas, I'd be glad to try them.
@Jakub Beránek I'd recommend posting in #t-compiler/performance and seeing if @nnethercote or @lqd has some things you could help out with :smile:
not a newcomer ofc, but ready to help :smile:
Hello all! In addition to the rustc dev guide, when I was starting (and we're all eternally students, really :innocent:) I found it really fun and rewarding to read the compiler crates API docs.

I would like first say hi and salute to the community and compiler team, as a newcomer to the internals of Rust (I have tried using rust to port and write an os around 10kLoC before, though). I am interested in the I-unsound issues and MIR tooling, also a big shout out to @oli , @pnkfelix and @Xavier Denis (sorry if the mentions interrupt). Currently I have been surfing the rustc source code, the dev guide and the doc, but not having much experience following a specific issue or solving a specific problem. Please let me know if there is anything I can start with or help out.

Hi @Jaic1 one good way to get into compiler work is via writing lints. There are several unsoundness issues that we could write lints for. If that sounds like something you'd like to do, we can start brainstorming in #clippy which bug to start with and how to best go about it.
@oli Thanks for your suggestion and will follow that way.
I just found the "ease writing new backends" aspiration is relevant to a question about MIR semantics I recently have been thinking of, also want to say hi to @scottmcm .

Hey all, @simulacrum, I'm interested in helping out with the performance dashboard. I've been learning Rust for a year now and have some statistics/data analysis knowledge from my background in physics. Would appreciate some guidance on how I can make myself useful :)

Hi @Michael Wigard -- #t-compiler/performance is a good place to ask questions or make suggestions. I think given your statistical background (at least more than most of us :) a good place to start might be https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/blob/master/docs/comparison-analysis.md, which gives a description of the current analysis used by our monitoring infra to determine whether to highlight a given set of metrics as a statistically significant change (and one that is relevant to users). You might have some opinions there or suggestions for improvement :)

Beyond that, it probably makes sense to sync up on the #t-compiler/performance channel with what you'd be interested in working on -- performance optimization in the compiler, maybe helping some of the others on the performance team with their analyses/measurements/etc, improvements to backend/frontend -- definitely plenty of work to go around. :)
Thanks, will have a look!
I’m flattered to be cited in this thread but I’d hardly say that I know what I’m doing when it comes to contributing to rustc
I’m mainly a heavy api user and Zulip lurker
But I’m aiming to change that in 2022

Jaic1 said:

sorry if the mentions interrupt

FYI there are two kinds of mentions on Zulip:

  • @**Jaic1** which will alert, and
  • @_**Jaic1** which will not.

(Both will auto-complete.)
scottmcm Thanks for the helpful tip :smile:

Hi all! I'm Nashe, an early career software engineer based in England. I've been using Rust for a few years and I finally decided to bite the bullet and contribute to the compiler. I have some experience with compilers (LLVM and type theory) and I spend most of my time doing kernel-level stuff. I'm mainly interested in the debugging and P-high aspirations: would @pnkfelix @Wesley Wiser and @apiraino be able to point me somewhere to start?
Hi @Nashe Mncube ! If you have experience with LLVM, I think there's a slew of LLVM-related issues that you might be well-suited to help us with.
Thanks @pnkfelix for getting back to me, and yes, I’m happy to pick up some LLVM issues!

Great @Nashe Mncube . The best place to start is probably the ICEBreaker-LLVM issue list. (There is also the broader super-set of all LLVM issues, but I suspect the ones tagged ice breaker are better when your'e getting started.)

I would also recommend familiarizing yourself with the #t-compiler/wg-llvm stream; there are individual topics there for ongoing conversations, and you can open up new topics dedicated to any particular issue that you want to discuss with the other people working on LLVM aspects of rustc.
Thanks @pnkfelix , I’ll have a looksy

Hi, I am a software engineer from India with 3.5 years of experience. I had submitted a PR to rustc last year here. I am interested in contributing more to rustc this year. I am interested in working on faster builds aspiration i.e. either of parallel compilation or inter-crate sharing aspirations. @pnkfelix , @Wesley Wiser (parallel compilation) or @nnethercote , @lqd (inter-crate sharing aspirations), can you point me to something I can start with?
Also would be happy to help on const generics/const eval (@lcnr )

hi @Vikram Pal, welcome back! We have dedicated streams where working groups coordinate work for both parallel compilation and performance. (same for const generics and const eval). They are good places to visit after asking here.

A couple thoughts:

  • the parallel compilation effort is somewhat stalled, and am not sure about its status. There is a meeting proposal so that t-compiler can discuss it, but it has not been yet selected for the next few rounds of meetings they'll be having because there are more important topics, that are technically related (as all this revolves around the query system, incremental compilation etc).

I've tried it quite recently and noticed that is stil compiles (it's tested on CI) but doesn't quite work as expected when actually turining parallel compilation on: there are a bunch of non-deterministic ICEs, of 2 types. One is related to incremental compilation (but IIRC they disappeared when turning that off), and the other is related to MIR stealing (and this would be orchestration/ordering concerns I'd say). So testing and analyzing this could be an interesting entry point although I'm not sure how hard that would be. I'm even less sure how hard it'd be to fix (I'm not participating in the parallel compilation effort myself, yet) and I know that the wg members usually have a lot of other things to do and not much time to devote to the effort.

• compiler performance in general: the wg has a topic dedicated to ready to go tasks although I don't think we have talked about any directly related to "inter-crate sharing".

I'm not quite sure what you mean about that, and doesn't ring a bell, but we can talk about it in another topic there if that's of interest. I believe that we do have something a little bit related in spirit, which would be to improve pipelining so that more of the crate compilation work could be overlapped. That would improve both inter-crate parallel compilation (via cargo's parallelism, not rustc's) and build caching (a kind of inter-crate sharing but probably not as you thought?), by e.g. allowing overlap whenever there's codegen, by splitting linking from compiling. Work on this is very advanced, it's not clear to me how "done" it is yet. So it could require more work on rustc, and in cargo itself to coordinate these new phases.

• const generics and const eval: for these two, I suggest going to the streams above and asking there directly, in particular lcnr whom you've pinged, but also boxy, oli, ralfj, BN should then be able to take it from there and point you towards tasks.

lqd said:

  • compiler performance in general: the wg has a topic dedicated to ready to go tasks although I don't think we have talked about any directly related to "inter-crate sharing".

I'm not quite sure what you mean about that, and doesn't ring a bell, but we can talk about it in another topic there if that's of interest. I believe that we do have something maybe a little bit related in spirit (but probably not in practice), which would be to improve pipelining so that more of the crate compilation work could be overlapped. That would improve both inter-crate parallel compilation (via cargo's parallelism, not rustc's) and build caching, by e.g. allowing overlap whenever there's codegen by splitting linking from compiling. Work on this is very advanced, it's not clear to me how "done" it is yet. So it could require more work on rustc, and in cargo itself to coordinate these new phases.

Regarding the inter-crate sharing, I saw it on this page but I understand this may be advanced.

ah I see now, yes! nnethercote would indeed be able to guide you towards some of these tasks. opening a topic about it in the performance stream would be the next step.
similarly for the other topics mentioned above, so that each members of the dedicated wgs you're interested in can help and give more information

Vikram Pal said:

but I understand this may be advanced.

To be clear, by "very advanced" I didn't mean one's skill-level to work on this, but the level of completion of the task itself: it's likely almost complete in rustc and ready to go. Checking that would be easy to do, there are open issues, internals threads, etc to see what remains to be done.
It's likely that cargo doesn't completely support this yet, so there it could be more work than in rustc.

lqd said:

Vikram Pal said:

but I understand this may be advanced.

To be clear, by "very advanced" I didn't mean one's skill-level to work on this, but the level of completion of the task itself: it's likely almost complete in rustc and ready to go. Checking that would be easy to do, there are open issues, internals threads, etc to see what remains to be done.
It's likely that cargo doesn't completely support this yet, so there it could be more work than in rustc.

Oh ok I understand now :sweat_smile:
for the inter-crate sharing tasks themselves (rather thank the linking-related ones I was mentioning) I'm not sure yet, we'll have to check with nnethercote
ok let me create a topic for it and move the discussion there

Hey there!

I'd like to get involved in the 2022 compiler initiatives! Taking the advice from the blog post I think helping out with the Diagnostic Aspirations would be a good place for me to start. @Esteban Küber, can you please let me know what I can do to get started?
@Esteban Küber A while ago I read https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/stable-diagnostic-affecting-attribute-with-unstable-api/16368 and I'm interested in helping out. How can I help?
I assume the first step is writing a RFC?
Hi @mejrs ! This sounds like a language initiative to me, for which we have a more structured process with hopefully less initial overhead than jumping directly to an RFC would entail

Lang initiatives are described at a high-level here: https://lang-team.rust-lang.org/initiatives.html, and the process for driving new initiatives is here: https://lang-team.rust-lang.org/initiatives/process.html

since you were saying "I assume the first step is writing an RFC", then that implies to me that you might be willing to take on ownership of this inititiative? Which would be great; you can of course get guidance from @Esteban Küber as to the details of what they envisage, but drive the work forward yourself. The main next step then, as described on that process page, is to open a proposal as an issue on the lang-team repository.
